description.short: A feature-rich role with many technologies across many levels. Vue based development, setting up docker servers, running bash scripts for SQL migrations, to building custom Vue component library.
description.long: I work with client team on a wide range of technologies to deliver innovative and flexible solutions to clients in gambling sector. I am responsible for development of widgets across wide selection of technologies and services, from visual side of things to functionality, frequently moving between FE and BE in order to set everything up and populate correctly, touching up on both SCSS and SQL, not shying away from bash scripts, using Invision, most of development is done using Vue and custom built Vue based platform

description.short: A mid-weight developer position in a well established full service digital agency with a goal to train and grow to a senior web developer and team lead role in the near future.
description.long: I work closely with Frontend and Backend teams to evaluate and improve current development cycle, research and present new technologies to the office to further optimize the development process and bring both teams closer together for a tighter collaboration and seamless integration of their work. Of course I still have a hand in front end web development, fleshing out designs and building a pleasant browsing experience across all media and devices, to a high code standard and with accessibility in mind. A broad selection of tools are used on a daily basis, Visual studio and Sublime are the IDEs of choice for our developers, TFS for version control and LESS/Handlebars mixture for quick and efficient BEM prototyping before merging a website with Umbraco/Sitecore functionality.

description.short: Amazing place to work at, utmost attention to detail, great relationship with clients, full support from back end developers and always great care to deliver a website that everyone in the office can be proud to put their name on.
long: My responsibilities include a full front end package – HTML, CSS (SASS) and JS (Vanilla, Jquery, Prototype),integrating designs into a PHP based back end system called Spirit, I interact with PHP on a regular basis and while I don’t write any from scratch I frequently interact with existing scripts, copying and editing when necessary, sometimes creating entire modules from existing pieces. After finalizing the project brief with the client, our UX designers build a framework that Digital Designers flesh out and create a full design from, including an asset sheet and interaction patterns, and sometimes reusable blocks too.

Then Front end developers take it apart and build a fully responsive, cross browser tested, interactive and animated site. At the same time PHP developers build new modules for our bespoke CMS and prepare additional functionality for the site if required, ready to be merged with front end. After Spirit and front end code is merged and turned into a fully functional site UX and UI designers go over the whole process and make sure it flows just as intended, if not – additional revisions are added and the whole site is tweaked to be the best it can be.
Versioning is done with Git and Codebase, most of which is managed through terminal, including SASS compiler and branch hierarchy.

description.short: Management and maintenance of existing websites and completed projects. Front end development of new projects based on bespoke .NET shopping platforms
long: CodeChange specialized in bespoke .NET Ecommerce and Elearning platforms. After client gathering requirements they are customized in accordance with the clients needs.
Then or during this process a design was being established and passed on to front end team to be built on top of said platforms.

My work involved the front end side of the process – turning a design into fully functional website, building on top of .NET functionality using partial views and master pages and linking all the functionality and generated data to the right places on design and making it interactive if needed.
I was responsible for my own workload and time management, as well as negotiations with projects client during build and after submission, and passing the project on to another developer.

Key technologies used were HTML, CSS and JS, focusing mainly on the first two, replacing any JS possible with CSS animations, checklist toggle nav menu would be an example. All the code was managed via Github versioning between all developers involved.
JS and Jquery involved heavy use of third party plugins for sliders, slider zoom, fancyboxes, drop downs, browser caching, cookies etc.

projects.title: SVG Moscow metro map
projects.description: Heavily inspired by csstubemap, I thought that yes, HTML/CSS map is great idea, but on paper its completely unmanageable and unusable if you want to add any kind of data manipulation, sorting, shortest-path algorithms etc. After some research the only reasonable solution was SVG - a clean, clear, and elegant way of keeping the map maintainable without the hassle, its SEO friendly, its compliant with any standards, and its fully accessible to JS in a semantic and meaningful way, so data manipulation will be much more accessible and enjoyable task. I'm specifically interested in implementing A* search algorithm

projects.title: webGL 3D model manipulation
description: Apparently I have a surprising passion for browser games done right. Most of browser games you see today are flash based, and anything even remotely close to webGL and HTML5 Canvas implementation is either nonexistent or done poorly and can barely be called a game. There are a few pleasant exception though, Play Canvas and Little workshop being the most notable ones.

I am exceedingly curious to play with this tech myself and see what I can do with this, how far can this be pushed, and even though JS is not an ideal language for expansive browser games - maybe a city management genre would fit it the best. So playing with a house model, setup its building order, 3D view and manipulation, hide/show individual elements etc. and maybe someday push it further than a single model.

projects.title: Pure CSS dynamic city
projects.description: Heavily inspired by Tiny city, and as a healthy (but very unmanageable) alternative to webGL, this seems like a curious thing to try - create a few buildings, preset conditions and flexible variables, and generate a city based on set parameters. Yes its fairly basic, but how amazing would be it to create an always unique HTML/CSS city with a press of a button!

projects.title: Recreate Pillars of Eternity dialogue tree
projects.description: A while back I've read very thought provoking article Designing Musical User Interfaces, I am not a designer, but it made me wonder when was the last time I used an audio file in my web development? In fact, was there even a first time? It seems baffling that such an obvious stimulus as sound is being completely ignored and even shunned in web development world. So I thought it would be an interesting experiment to combine a favourite characters dialogue - text and audio and interactions - with web development and audio files for an immersive experience. This will give me plenty of room to experiment with audio formats, and sound integration into a website.

projects.title: D3js family tree
projects.description: Recently I have dabbled with D3js, an amazing and very powerful library for data manipulation. A complex tool that gives huge control over data formatting, outputting and shaping it in any way imaginable. This coincided with my personal curiosity for my family tree and finding lost relatives - there turned out to be a whole lot of them. The best way to visualise them all, keep a record, and present all the research and work done to all of them is a tree diagram. A very familiar and widely accepted genealogy depiction tool, and with proper formatting and rich data it can be a gorgeous and impressive data showcase.
